title: Exercises: Leadership, Team Support & Conflict Resolution

items.title: Exercise 1: Feedback Email (Doc A)
items.text:
Doc A — Internal Feedback

To: Alex Taylor
From: Sarah Jenkins (Operations Manager)
Subject: Project Feedback – Office Refurbishment

Hi Alex,

I wanted to provide some feedback on your leadership during the office refurbishment project. I was particularly impressed by how you **anticipated our needs** by having the new furniture delivered on Friday evening, avoiding any disruption to the team on Monday morning.

You showed great **initiative** when you got the IT team to reconfigure the server room ahead of schedule. Your **accountability** when the floor tiling was delayed was also noted; rather than just flagging the issue, you proposed a solution to have the contractors work on Saturday morning to stay on track.

You have set an excellent example for the junior coordinators. Let’s touch base on Wednesday to discuss how we can empower you to **take the lead** on the Q4 budget planning.

Best,
Sarah

### Highlighted Vocabulary
1. **Anticipating Needs**: Identifying what a manager needs before they ask for it (e.g., preparing a briefing pack before a meeting).
2. **Initiative**: The ability to assess and initiate things independently.
3. **Accountability**: Taking ownership of processes and being responsible for the outcome, whether positive or negative.
4. **Take the lead**: To take the main responsibility for a task.

questions.question: How did Alex show 'anticipating needs' according to the email?
options: By asking Sarah for help.
By having the furniture delivered on Friday evening.
By taking a holiday on Monday.
questions.explanation: Doc A states: 'impressed by how you anticipated our needs by having the new furniture delivered on Friday evening'.

questions.question: What did Alex do when the floor tiling was delayed that showed 'accountability'?
options: He blamed the contractors.
He just told Sarah it was late.
He proposed a solution to have contractors work on Saturday.
questions.explanation: Doc A mentions: 'rather than just flagging the issue, you proposed a solution to have the contractors work on Saturday morning'.

items.prompt: Exercise 2: Leadership Traits. What does 'mentorship' involve in an administrative context?
options: Only following orders from the CEO.
Helping junior staff understand office protocols and culture.
Doing everyone else's work for them.
Strictly monitoring everyone's lunch breaks.
items.explanation: Mentorship involves supporting and helping new or junior staff members with protocols and culture.

items.prompt: Exercise 3: Managing Up. When 'managing up', what is the recommended approach if you identify a problem?
options: Wait for your manager to find it themselves.
Send an email immediately complaining about it.
Flag the issue and propose at least one potential solution.
Tell your manager it's not your responsibility.
items.explanation: An effective strategy for managing up is to 'Provide Solutions, Not Problems' by proposing a solution when flagging an issue.

items.prompt: Exercise 4: Delegation Vocabulary. Complete the sentence: 'I need to ___ Sam ___ on this project so he can help with the documentation.'
options: touch / base
loop / in
set / example
take / lead
items.explanation: To 'loop someone in' means to include them in a discussion or project.

items.prompt: Exercise 5: Causative Forms. Rewrite this sentence using 'have + object + past participle': 'I told the printer company to fix the photocopier.'
items.modelAnswer: I had the photocopier fixed.

items.prompt: Exercise 6: Causative Forms. Rewrite this sentence using 'get + person + to + infinitive': 'I persuaded IT to install the new software.'
items.modelAnswer: I got IT to install the new software.

items.prompt: Exercise 7: Extracting Action Points. Based on Doc A, list the 3 specific examples of Alex's initiative and leadership mentioned by Sarah.
items.modelAnswer:
1. Having furniture delivered on Friday evening.
2. Getting IT to reconfigure the server room early.
3. Proposing a solution for the tiling delay (Saturday work).

items.prompt: Exercise 8: Courtesy Modals. Which is the most professional way to delegate a task to a junior colleague while 'managing expectations'?
options: Do this by tomorrow, no excuses.
Would you be able to handle the data entry? I'll need it by Wednesday morning. Does that timeframe work for you?
I'm giving you this because I'm too busy.
Sam, do the data entry now.
items.explanation: This option is polite, sets a clear deadline, and checks for feasibility (managing expectations).

items.prompt: Exercise 9: Follow-up Email. Write a 50-word email to Sarah (from Doc A) 'touching base' before your Wednesday meeting. Mention one 'solution' you have for the Q4 budget planning.
items.modelAnswer: Hi Sarah, looking forward to touching base on Wednesday. Regarding the Q4 budget, I’ve had the preliminary data audited and have a proposal to streamline our vendor payments which could save us 5%. I’ll bring the details to our meeting. Thanks, Alex

items.prompt: Exercise 10: Operational Logic. If you 'delegate' a task to a junior, who remains ultimately 'accountable' for the outcome according to the theory?
options: The junior colleague
The senior who delegated it
The IT department
Nobody
items.explanation: Accountability involves taking ownership of the outcome, even when tasks are delegated.

questions.question: Which stage of the L.E.A.P. framework does the speaker use when saying 'I understand this delay is frustrating'?
options: Listen
Empathize
Problem-solve
questions.explanation: Acknowledging the other person's feelings is the 'Empathize' stage.

questions.question: What causative structure does the speaker use to propose a solution?
options: I'll have the reports sent tomorrow.
I'll get IT to check the system.
I'll have my assistant call you.
questions.explanation: The speaker says they will get IT to check the system, using 'get + person + to + infinitive'.

questions.question: How does the administrator adapt to the manager's preference for a 'dashboard view'?
options: By reading out every line of the budget.
By presenting a one-page summary with red/green status indicators.
By sending a long email with attachments.
questions.explanation: A dashboard view requires high-level, visual, and concise summaries.

questions.question: What is the primary goal of 'managing up' as described in the briefing?
options: To manipulate the manager's decisions.
To align with the manager's goals to achieve better results.
To delegate all tasks to junior staff.
questions.explanation: Managing up is about alignment and working effectively with superiors.

items.prompt: Exercise 13: Leadership Reflection (Portfolio). Write a 200-word reflection on a time you took initiative. Use at least 3 causative forms (e.g., 'I had the reports audited', 'I got the team to...').
items.modelAnswer: Last quarter, I noticed our filing system was becoming inefficient. I took the initiative to streamline the process. First, I had the old archives moved to off-site storage to free up space. Then, I got the IT department to set up a new digital indexing tool. I also had the junior staff attend a training session on the new system. As a result, our retrieval time improved by 40%. This showed leadership by anticipating the team's needs for better data access.

items.prompt: Exercise 14: Delegation Table. Complete this table with 3 tasks you would delegate. Format: Task | Owner | Instruction (using 'get someone to do').
items.modelAnswer: 1. Data entry | Sam | Get Sam to enter the Q3 receipts. 2. Room booking | Jane | Get Jane to book the board room. 3. IT Support | Mike | Get Mike to fix the server login.

items.prompt: Exercise 15: Weekly Mini-test. 1) Define 'Accountability'. 2) What does 'Managing Up' mean? 3) Form a sentence: 'Have + [my report] + [update]'. 4) Form a sentence: 'Get + [IT] + [to help]'.
items.modelAnswer: 1) Taking ownership and responsibility for outcomes. 2) Working effectively with your boss for best results. 3) I had my report updated. 4) I got IT to help.

items.title: Exercise 16: De-escalation Strategy (Doc B)
items.text:
Doc B — Standard Operating Procedure: Conflict Resolution

When a conflict arises, administrators must follow the **L.E.A.P. Framework** to **de-escalate** the situation. This approach ensures that the client or colleague feels heard while focusing on a professional outcome.

Steps:
1. **Listen**: Allow the speaker to finish without interruption.
2. **Empathize**: Use phrases like 'I understand why this is a concern'.
3. **Apologize**: Say 'I'm sorry for the inconvenience' even if not at fault.
4. **Problem-solve**: Identify a **compromise** or a clear path forward.

### Highlighted Vocabulary
1. **De-escalate**: To reduce the intensity of a conflict or potentially violent situation.
2. **Framework**: A basic structure underlying a system, concept, or text.
3. **Compromise**: An agreement or a settlement of a dispute that is reached by each side making concessions.

questions.question: According to Doc B, what is the primary goal of the L.E.A.P. Framework?
options: To win the argument
To de-escalate the situation
To ignore the complaint
questions.explanation: The text states the framework is used to de-escalate the situation.

questions.question: Which step involves saying 'I understand why this is a concern'?
options: Listen
Empathize
Problem-solve
questions.explanation: The SOP identifies this phrase as part of the Empathize step.

items.prompt: Exercise 17: SBI Model. You are giving feedback to a colleague who was late to a meeting. Which is the 'Impact' part of the SBI model?
options: In the 9 AM team meeting this morning...
...you arrived 15 minutes late...
...which meant we had to restart the agenda and lost valuable time.
You are always late and it's annoying.
items.explanation: The Impact section explains how the specific behavior affected the situation or team.

items.prompt: Exercise 18: Causative Matching. Change 'I cleaned the office' into a professional causative form (someone else did it).
items.modelAnswer: I had the office cleaned.

items.prompt: Exercise 19: Conflict Resolution. What is the benefit of using 'I' statements during a disagreement?
options: It makes you sound more selfish.
It reduces defensiveness in the other person by focusing on your experience.
It allows you to blame the other person more effectively.
It is only used in informal settings.
items.explanation: 'I' statements focus on facts and personal impact rather than accusing the other person.

items.prompt: Exercise 20: Vocabulary Practice. Use 'de-escalate' and 'common ground' in a single sentence about a workplace dispute.
items.modelAnswer: I tried to de-escalate the situation by finding common ground regarding our shared goal of finishing the project on time.

items.prompt: Exercise 21: Managing Up. Your boss gives you a task with a very vague deadline. What should you do?
options: Wait until they ask for it.
Clarify expectations by asking for a specific 'due date' and priority level.
Guess and hope for the best.
Complain to your colleagues.
items.explanation: Clarifying expectations is a core strategy for managing up effectively.

items.prompt: Exercise 22: Causative 'Have'. Form a sentence: 'The manager / have / the staff / attend / the workshop'. (No 'to')
items.modelAnswer: The manager had the staff attend the workshop.

items.prompt: Exercise 23: De-escalation. If a colleague is shouting at you, what is the best first step?
options: Shout back to show you are not afraid.
Remain calm, use a low voice, and ask if you can discuss the matter in a private room.
Ignore them completely and walk away without a word.
Call security immediately without talking to them.
items.explanation: Remaining calm and moving to a private space helps de-escalate the intensity.

items.prompt: Exercise 24: Feedback Transformation. Transform this judgmental comment into an SBI feedback: 'You are so disorganized with the files!'
items.modelAnswer: In the filing system update (Situation), I noticed many documents were mislabelled (Behavior), which caused a 2-hour delay in the audit (Impact).

items.prompt: Exercise 25: Vocabulary. What does it mean to 'iron out the details'?
options: To press a shirt for a meeting.
To resolve minor problems or clarify small points.
To cancel a project entirely.
To find a new vendor.
items.explanation: To iron out details means to fix small issues or finalize specifics.

items.prompt: Exercise 26: Delegation Instruction. You need a junior to proofread a report. Use 'get + person + to + infinitive'.
items.modelAnswer: I'll get Mark to proofread the report.

items.prompt: Exercise 27: Leadership. Which action best demonstrates 'anticipating needs'?
options: Doing exactly what you are told.
Preparing a travel itinerary and local weather report before the executive asks for them.
Asking for a pay rise.
Wait for a problem to happen before suggesting a fix.
items.explanation: Anticipating needs means acting before being asked based on logical foresight.

items.prompt: Exercise 28: L.E.A.P. Practice. Write an 'Apology' sentence for a lost invoice, following the L.E.A.P. framework.
items.modelAnswer: I apologize for the oversight regarding the missing invoice; I understand this affects your payment cycle.

items.prompt: Exercise 29: Accountability. If a project fails because of a vendor's mistake, an 'accountable' administrator would:
options: Blame the vendor and do nothing else.
Take responsibility for the oversight and present a plan to resolve the issue with the vendor.
Tell the boss they didn't pick the vendor.
Delete the project files.
items.explanation: Accountability means taking ownership of the outcome and finding solutions, regardless of external factors.

items.prompt: Exercise 30: Causative 'Get'. Rewrite: 'The CEO persuaded the board to increase the budget.'
items.modelAnswer: The CEO got the board to increase the budget.

items.title: Exercise 31: Professional Feedback (Doc C)
items.text:
Doc C — The SBI Model for Growth

To maintain a healthy team environment, feedback must be objective. We use the **SBI Model** (Situation, Behavior, Impact). When giving feedback, it is important to find **common ground** and aim to **meet halfway** if there are disagreements about the cause of an issue.

Key Principles:
- Focus on observable actions, not character.
- Explain how the action affected the department's **accountability**.
- Agree on an action plan to avoid recurrence.

### Highlighted Vocabulary
1. **Common Ground**: Shared interests or beliefs between disagreeing parties.
2. **Meet Halfway**: To compromise with someone to reach an agreement.
3. **Accountability**: The obligation to account for activities and accept responsibility.

questions.question: What does the SBI model stand for in Doc C?
options: Status, Budget, Increase
Situation, Behavior, Impact
Secret, Basic, Important
questions.explanation: The text defines SBI as Situation, Behavior, Impact.

questions.question: Why should you try to 'meet halfway' during a feedback disagreement?
options: To avoid talking to the person
To reach an agreement through compromise
To admit you are wrong
questions.explanation: Meeting halfway is defined as compromising to reach an agreement.

items.prompt: Exercise 32: Professional Email. Write a 30-word email 'looping in' a colleague to a thread about office supplies.
items.modelAnswer: Hi Jane, I'm looping you in here as you manage the stationary budget. Could you review the latest quote from the vendor? Thanks, Sam.

items.prompt: Exercise 33: SBI Model. In SBI, 'Behavior' should be:
options: An opinion about the person's character.
A specific, observable action.
A guess about why they did something.
A suggestion for the future.
items.explanation: Behavior must be objective and observable, not an interpretation of intent.

items.prompt: Exercise 34: Causative Practice. Change 'I arranged for the caterers to bring lunch' using 'had + person + infinitive'.
items.modelAnswer: I had the caterers bring lunch.

items.prompt: Exercise 35: Emotional Intelligence. Which trait is most useful for 'de-escalating' a heated argument?
options: Aggression
Self-regulation
Stubbornness
Indifference
items.explanation: Self-regulation allows you to stay calm and not react emotionally, which is key to de-escalation.

items.prompt: Exercise 36: Strategy. Explain how 'providing solutions, not problems' helps your relationship with your manager.
items.modelAnswer: It saves their time and demonstrates that you are taking ownership of the situation, building trust and showing initiative.

items.prompt: Exercise 37: Vocabulary. A 'briefing' is:
options: A very long document.
A short meeting or document giving essential information.
A formal legal trial.
A type of office furniture.
items.explanation: A briefing is intended to provide necessary info concisely.

items.prompt: Exercise 38: Causative 'Have'. Rewrite: 'I need to pay someone to audit the accounts.'
items.modelAnswer: I need to have the accounts audited.

items.prompt: Exercise 39: Mentorship. Why is mentorship important in administration?
options: To make sure nobody ever takes a break.
To ensure knowledge transfer and maintain consistent standards in office protocols.
To find out secrets about colleagues.
To delegate all your own work to someone else.
items.explanation: Mentorship ensures the team remains efficient and adheres to company culture/standards.

items.prompt: Exercise 40: L.E.A.P. Problem-Solving. A colleague is upset because they weren't invited to a meeting. Write a 'Problem-solve' sentence.
items.modelAnswer: I will send you the minutes immediately and make sure you are added to all future sessions on this topic.

items.prompt: Exercise 41: Managing Up. If your manager's style is 'dashboard view', you should provide:
options: A 20-page detailed report.
A one-page summary with key metrics and red/green status indicators.
A verbal update over coffee.
No information until the project is 100% finished.
items.explanation: Dashboard view implies high-level, visual, and concise data.

items.prompt: Exercise 42: Causative 'Get'. Rewrite: 'I convinced the manager to give us a day off.'
items.modelAnswer: I got the manager to give us a day off.

items.prompt: Exercise 43: Vocabulary. To 'call a truce' means:
options: To fire everyone.
To agree to stop an argument temporarily.
To start a new business.
To win a negotiation.
items.explanation: Calling a truce is a temporary cessation of conflict.

items.prompt: Exercise 44: Objective Language. Rewrite this emotive sentence professionally: 'This schedule is a total disaster!'
items.modelAnswer: The current schedule has several significant conflicts that need to be addressed.

items.prompt: Exercise 45: Final Review. Which causative form is most common when paying for a professional service?
options: Get someone to do
Have something done
Have someone do
Make someone do
items.explanation: 'Have something done' is standard for services (e.g., 'have the car serviced', 'have the audit performed').
